docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Israel Strikes at Gaza; Powell Criticizes Sharon Israeli land, sea and air forces attacked targets in the Gaza Strip, where Palestinians breached another red line on Tuesday when they fired rockets into an Israeli town. With the escalating carnage, 10 Palestinians and 2 Israelis were added to the death toll. In Washington, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell challenged Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's statement that if Israel continued to increase Palestinian losses the leaders would sit down to talks. A1 Palestinian militants tied to Yasir Arafat's Fatah faction have carried out the most attacks -- and the most lethal attacks -- both sides say. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: In an effort to allow the state to begin paying its Medicaid bills again, the Legislature approved, and Gov. Ronnie Musgrove immediately signed, an unpopular package mandating cuts in payments to health care providers; a tripling, to $3, in the price of patients' drug co-payments; and an appropriation of $108 million from the state's tobacco-suit trust fund. The Mississippi Medicaid program was running a deficit of $158 million when it ran out of cash in February.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Medicaid Bailout

docs.abstract: Legislature approves and Gov Ronnie Musgrove signs unpopular package designed to let Mississippi resume paying Medicaid bills; program was running $158 million deficit when it ran out of cash in Feb; package includes cuts in payments to health care providers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A FEW months ago, Dr. Jennifer Breznay began to notice something different about some of her patients at the Montefiore medical office in the north Bronx. Some had health problems that they had long ignored. Or arrived with ailments that they used to take to the emergency room. Or had no ailments at all but had developed a sudden interest in preventive care. ''Suddenly, people who had gone without for years were accessing the health care system,'' Dr. Breznay said this week.

headline.main: Metro Matters; The Doctor Will See You, For Now

docs.abstract: Joyce Purnick comments on large number of previously uninsured patients showing up at doctors' offices and medical centers in New York City, noting they are taking advantage of 'rare and strange' window of opportunity created by Sept 11 attack on World Trade Center; notes that with computers knocked out and people in distress, Gov Pataki created disaster-relief Medicaid program in mid-September, providing most applicants with four months of coverage or longer, since coverage is being extended until people apply for recertification (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gifford Miller, the speaker of the City Council, offered a rare glimpse of the new Council's vision for the city yesterday, focusing on cuts to children's services and raising taxes as potential battle lines in budget negotiations with the Bloomberg administration. ''There are areas of the mayor's plan that cause both myself and my colleagues great concern, deep cuts that may seem necessary in the short term but could cost us dearly in the long run,'' Mr. Miller told a group of business and civic leaders attending a breakfast meeting of the Association for a Better New York. After listing cuts to subsidized day care and after-school programs as examples, Mr. Miller added, ''The mayor says there are no sacred cows, but I believe there should perhaps be one: education.'' Nonetheless, Mr. Miller stopped short of promising to block trimming of the education budget, saying that he had not yet ruled anything out or anything in.

headline.main: Council Speaker Outlines Potential Battles With Mayor

docs.abstract: New York City Council speaker Gifford Miller offers rare glimpse of new Council's vision for city, focusing on cuts to children's services and raising taxes as potential battle lines in budget negotiations with Bloomberg administration, speech to Assn for a Better New York; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush took some of the broadest federal action in two decades to protect a major American industry today, imposing tariffs of up to 30 percent on most types of steel imported into the United States from Europe, Asia and South America. The tariffs will last three years, he said, to give American steel producers time to consolidate operations and stem layoffs. Mr. Bush's action is likely to send the price of steel up sharply, perhaps as much as 10 percent, a cost American consumers will ultimately bear in higher prices for autos, appliances and housing. The United States imports about a quarter of the steel it consumes, though Mr. Bush exempted steel made in Mexico, Canada and developing nations from the tariffs announced today. The nations hardest hit are Japan, South Korea, China, Taiwan, Germany and Brazil.

headline.main: BUSH PUTS TARIFFS OF AS MUCH AS 30% ON STEEL IMPORTS

docs.abstract: Pres Bush imposes tariffs of up to 30 percent on most types of steel imports for three years to give American producers time to consolidate and stem layoffs; unusually broad move is likely to boost prices by as much as 10 percent; exempts Mexico, Canada and developing nations; nations hardest hit are Japan, South Korea, China, Taiwan, Germany and Brazil; European nations and Japan plan challenge before World Trade Organization on grounds 'import surge' Bush cites as justification ended in 1998; imports have fallen 27.5 percent since 1998, but prices have also fallen sharply; Bush takes no action on bailout of up to $12 billion to cover pension and health care costs for retired workers from bankrupt steel companies; group representing companies that buy steel scores move, hailed by steel industry and its unions; table; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans drafting legislation to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare said today that they would encourage the use of low-cost generic drugs as an alternative to brand-name medicines and would try to persuade drug makers to curtail advertising, which has been blamed for rising costs. In the three years that lawmakers have been debating ways to add prescription drug coverage to Medicare, this is the first time that a consensus has developed among legislative leaders in both parties favoring financial incentives for the use of generic drugs as a way to lower costs.
docs.abstract: House Republicans drafting bill to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare say they will encourage use of low-cost generic drugs and press drug makers to curb advertising, which has been blamed for rising costs; Rep Bill Thomas notes patents on many best-selling drugs will expire in next five years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Although the administration's plan to further curtail welfare dependency should be applauded (''Bush Urges Work and Marriage Programs in Welfare Plan,'' news article, Feb. 27), it continues to overlook the role that financial independence can play in promoting family values. Many of those who leave welfare for work become less financially secure because benefits begin to phase out at extremely low income levels. Allowing these workers to keep their health insurance, food stamps, housing subsidies and earned income tax credit supplements would encourage them to seek full-time work, take more demanding jobs and have additional family members enter the work force.
docs.abstract: Heather Rubeo letter on Feb 27 article says Bush administration overlooks role of financial independence in promoting family values for people leaving welfare for work

headline.main: Where to Go in Louisiana When the Music Dies

docs.abstract: Efforts are under way in New Orleans to honor local musicians who wrote and performed some of richest songs in its rich history, but died penniless and lay buried unrecognized in pauper's graves; money is being raised for tombstone for Jessie Hill, musical legend who died in 1996; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: General Electric allows its top executives to contribute money to a retirement fund on which the company recently guaranteed an annual return of at least 10 percent, far better than a typical G.E. worker saving money in the company's 401(k) plan can expect. Tenneco Automotive, which makes shock absorbers, permits its executives to receive a full pension at age 55, seven years before the company's other employees can.

headline.main: For Executives, Nest Egg Is Wrapped in a Security Blanket

docs.abstract: US corporations have developed two-tier pension system for workers and executives; companies seeking to increase profits have cut retirement benefits, leaving many members of baby boom generation unprepared for life after age 65 despite long bull market; executives have persuaded their directors to reward them with ever-larger pay packages; on top of millions in salary, bonus and stock options, many top managers have received pensions that are more generous than they once were and are often devoid of risk inherent in typical 401(k) plans that have replaced old company pension for many workers; some companies give their executives large annual payments and guaranteed investment returns; others pay premiums on life insurance policies for executives, allowing them, or their heirs, to collect cash payments decades after retirement; some specifics of retirement packages for General Electric chief executive Jeffrey R Immelt, Estee Lauder chief executive Fred Langhammer, American Airlines chief executive Donald J Carty and Tenneco Automotive chief executive Mark Frissora noted; photos (M)
